awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Enhancing STEM Recruitment, Retention and Engagement by Establishing the Shaw University Center for Computer Science Living, Learning and Research
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP), through Targeted Infusion Projects, supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue science, technology, engineering or mathematics (STEM) graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Shaw University addresses this goal as it seeks to enhance undergraduate computer science education by implementing and researching innovative, yet evidence-based strategies in the departments of biology, computer science, and mathematics. The project is guided by an on-going evaluation with a strong plan for formative and summative evaluation.

This project will implement and study four evidenced-based strategies to improve retention in computer science: social support within affinity groups; an enhanced first year curriculum; inquiry-based learning; and exposure to research and faculty mentoring. To provide social support, all incoming computer science majors will be grouped into a cohort-based affinity group and housed together. The first year curriculum in biology, computer science and mathematics for each incoming freshman computer science cohort will be enhanced and revised. Courses will incorporate inquiry based learning, programming, real-world data analysis and the applied use of technology. More advanced computer science students will be involved in research with faculty. This project will serve as a case study on how to  implement evidence-based teaching methods in the setting of this institution, which can then serve as a model at other institutions of similar mission and size.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this grant was to improve outcomes for minority students entering computer science and biology. Science and technology are fundamentally disciplines where more people will generate more ideas and move the field forward. However, minority students have traditionally had lower graduation rates in these fields. If this failure to graduate is created by social conditions we are denying the United States people who might otherwise push science and technology forward.

We specifically aimed to reduce the drop-out rate from these majors and to increase student's ability to do "real-world" work. To accomplish this we housed students together with other students with the same major, changed our curriculum, and opened up opportunities for students to work on research projects which were at least partly of their own choosing.

In computer science we saw an increase in new students coming to the major as well as a reduced drop-out rate, and in biology we saw  reduced failure rate (and hence drop-out rate) in the first-year courses. Furthermore, graduating students found themselves better able to answer questions at interviews and that their experience on their projects was very helpful in getting that first job out of college.

Students reported several key things about the way these interventions helped them. The housing arrangement allowed students to form study groups more easily and they reported a higher sense of community and involvement on campus. Students reported being brought "back in" by other students when they began to get frustrated or have issues with the school work. They reported higher overall engagement with their courses than students not receiving the curriculum modifications. Students also said that engagement in their projects gave them a sense of confidence that they could do well in their chosen major because they were seeing themselves succeed in real-world tasks. Finally, the ability to work one-on-one with a professor in these projects was cited as very important by many students. The aspect of mentorship allowed students to form closer connections to key faculty, which, in turn, meant that they had someone to ask for school and career advice who they trusted.


Last Modified: 07/06/2022
Modified by: Eric Butler
por.por_txt_cntn:
The aim of this grant was to improve outcomes for minority students  entering computer science and biology. Science and technology are  fundamentally disciplines where more people will generate more ideas and  move the field forward. However, minority students have traditionally  had lower graduation rates in these fields. If this failure to graduate  is created by social conditions we are denying the United States people  who might otherwise push science and technology forward.

We  specifically aimed to reduce the drop-out rate from these majors and to  increase student's ability to do "real-world" work. To accomplish this  we housed students together with other students with the same major,  changed our curriculum, and opened up opportunities for students to work  on research projects which were at least partly of their own choosing.

In  computer science we saw an increase in new students coming to the major  as well as a reduced drop-out rate, and in biology we saw  reduced  failure rate (and hence drop-out rate) in the first-year courses.  Furthermore, graduating students found themselves better able to answer  questions at interviews and that their experience on their projects was  very helpful in getting that first job out of college.

Students  reported several key things about the way these interventions helped  them. The housing arrangement allowed students to form study groups more  easily and they reported a higher sense of community and involvement on  campus. Students reported being brought "back in" by other students  when they began to get frustrated or have issues with the school work.  They reported higher overall engagement with their courses than students  not receiving the curriculum modifications. Students also said that  engagement in their projects gave them a sense of confidence that they  could do well in their chosen major because they were seeing themselves  succeed in real-world tasks. Finally, the ability to work one-on-one  with a professor in these projects was cited as very important by many  students. The aspect of mentorship allowed students to form closer  connections to key faculty, which, in turn, meant that they had someone  to ask for school and career advice who they trusted.
